intro: Cinchona ovata var. vulgaris, commonly known as the Peruvian bark, is a species native to the Andean regions of South America. It is characterized by its evergreen foliage and produces clusters of small, fragrant white flowers. The plant is a member of the Rubiaceae family and is known for its medicinal properties, particularly the alkaloid quinine, which has been historically used to treat malaria. Its bark contains various bioactive compounds that contribute to its therapeutic value. The plant thrives in tropical and subtropical climates with high humidity and well-drained soil.
